document.docAuthor: Arantes, Tiago & Souza-Shibatta, Lenice & Teixeira, Gustavo Monteiro
document.docTitle: Description of a new species of Aegla (Decapoda, Anomura) from the Paraná 3 hydrographic basin, Brazil

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Description of a new species of Aegla (Decapoda, Anomura) from the Paraná 3 hydrographic basin, Brazil

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Laboratório de Sistemática Molecular, Departamento de Biologia Animal e Vegetal, Universidade Estadual de Londrina, 86057-970, Londrina, Paraná, Brazil.

emphasis.docTitle:
Description of a new species of
Aegla
( Decapoda, Anomura ) from the Paraná 3 hydrographic basin, Brazil

subSection.paragraph: TIAGO ARANTES 1 , LENICE SOUZA-SHIBATTA 2 & GUSTAVO MONTEIRO TEIXEIRA 3

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Laboratório de Invertebrados Aquáticos e Simbiontes (LabIAS), Departamento de Biologia Animal e Vegetal, Universidade Estadual de Londrina, 86057-970, Londrina, Paraná , Brazil .

subSection.paragraph: � tiago.arantes18@uel.br; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7512-6455
� gmteixeira@uel.br; https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9378-8287

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Laboratório de Sistemática Molecular, Departamento de Biologia Animal e Vegetal, Universidade Estadual de Londrina, 86057-970, Londrina, Paraná , Brazil .

subSection.paragraph: � lenicesouza@hotmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8097-6895

Freshwater crustaceans of the genus
Aegla
are endemic to southern South America, and present greater richness in the river basins of the state of Rio Grande do Sul , Brazil . However, recent studies have shown the enormous potential for discovering new species of
Aegla
in the state of Paraná . In the last six year the number of species recorded has almost doubled, increasing from 9 to 16. In the present work, we expand the current knowledge about the diversity of
Aegla
in a set of poorly explored drainage basins in the western region of the state and describe a new species,
Aegla urussanga
n. sp.
, based on morphological and molecular evidence. A combination of morphological characters supports the new species: orbital spine absent, non-elevated epigastric prominences, robust protogastric lobes with scales, anterior dorsal margin of epimeron 2 armed and with pronounced concavity, sub-rectangular palmar crest of chelipeds, internal margin of the ventral face of the ischium of the cheliped with a proximal stout spine, a distal stout spine, and up to three tubercles with spiniform scales. The molecular data, based on partial COI sequences, also support the distinction of the new species from others that occur in adjacent river basins. The species with the smallest genetic distance from
A. urussanga
n. sp.
is
Aegla castro Schmitt, 1942
which occurs in the Iguaçu River basin. The new species occurs in distinct streams, probably interconnected in the past and currently isolated by the Itaipu reservoir and is the second species of
Aegla
described from the complex of drainage basins called Paraná 3 basin.

Key words : Crustacea ,
Aeglidae
, freshwater , South America

In the last six years, seven species of
Aegla
have been described from the state of Paraná , Brazil :
Aegla okora Páez & Teixeira, 2018
(
Páez et al . 2018
),
Aegla nebeccana Trombetta, Páez, Santos & Teixeira (
Trombetta et al . 2019
)
,
Aegla jacutinga Marçal & Teixeira, 2020
(
Marçal et al . 2020
),
Aegla buenoi Marçal & Teixeira, 2021
(Marçal et a l. 2021),
Aegla abrupta
,
A. nanopedis
,
A. santosi Marçal & Teixeira (Marçal et al . 2021)
.

Despite recent efforts by research groups, it is believed that knowledge of the diversity, biology, and ecology of
Aegla
is still scarce (Marçal et al . 2021). Among the least explored basins is the Paraná 3 basin (BP3), a sub-basin of the Upper Paraná River. This basin is not named after a single river, as it is made up of several micro-basins that drain directly into the Paraná River. It is located in the western region of the State of Paraná , between the Piquiri and Iguaçu rivers, comprising all the rivers and streams that flow directly into the Itaipu reservoir ( Pereira & Scroccaro 2010 ).

The current work carried out an inventory in an unexplored area in relation to the aeglid fauna, using morphological and molecular data, and presents the description of a new species for the Alto Paraná region , contributing to the knowledge of the distribution and richness of the genus.

Sampling was carried out in the region called BP3, located in the west of the state of Paraná , Brazil . In total, 10 streams were inventoried, which flow directly into the Paraná River, in the municipalities of: Itaipulândia, site 1, nameless stream, ( 25°09'13.1"S 54°15'03.1"W ); Portal do Ocoí, site 2, nameless stream, ( 25°08'22.4"S 54°09'14.6"W ); São Miguel do Iguaçu, site 3, nameless stream, ( 25°16'15.8"S 54°13'31.7"W ); Matelândia, site 4, Rio Xaxim ( 25°06'44.3"S 53°56'54.7"W ), site 5, Rio Sabiá ( 25°11'30.0"S 53°58'09.5"W ), site 6, nameless stream, ( 25°10'10.5"S 53°56'56.9"W ), site 7, nameless stream, ( 25°03'24.2"S 53°55'35.0"W ); Vera Cruz do Oeste, site 8, Córrego Surucuá ( 25°01'54.2"S 53°55'00.0"W ); Toledo, site 9, nameless stream, ( 24°48'43.3''S 53°42'31.3''W ), site 10, nameless stream, ( 24°51'47.2''S 53°45'35.7''W ) ( Fig. 1 ).

To capture the animals, the substrate was manually stirred so that the animals were carried by the current to a sieve (diameter = 60 cm , mesh size = 4 mm ). Ten specimens from each location were placed on crushed ice to be anesthetized. The abdominal muscle tissue was then removed for DNA extraction, and both the removed tissues and the entire specimens were fixed in absolute alcohol. The remaining individuals were preserved in 70% alcohol for morphological analysis. All specimens are deposited in the Crustacean Collection of the Zoology Museum of the State University of Londrina in lots: MZUEL 525, MZUEL 528, MZUEL 533, MZUEL 534, MZUEL 545, MZUEL 546, MZUEL 526, MZUEL 578, and MZUEL 579.

Descriptions are based on morphological characters of the holotype , with variations observed in the paratypes . The morphological terms used in the descriptions follow Martin & Abele (1988), Bond-Buckup & Buckup (1994) , and
Moraes et al . (2016)
. Measurements were made following the methods of Bond-Buckup and Buckup (1994) and Moraes et a l. (2016) with a precision caliper of 0.01mm and the aid of a stereoscopic microscope if necessary. The measures employed were: areolar anterior demarcation (AAD); areolar height (AH); areolar posterior margin (APM); carapace length including rostrum (CL); carapace length excluding rostrum (CLE); carapace width (CW); half the maximum width of the telson (HWT); lateral margin of the rostrum (LMR); pre-cervical width (PCW); mesial region of the posterior margin of the cephalothorax (PMC); rostral base width ( RBW ); transverse dorsal line length ( TDL ); width of uropod (WU); and abdominal width in females (AW). The shape of the rostrum, areola, cardiac area, and uropods was determined using the morphometric relationships described in
Moraes et al . (2016)
. Following the same authors, the ocular peduncles were positioned in parallel alignment with the rostrum to determine the extent of the apex of the anterolateral spine in relation to the basal margin of the cornea. A stereoscope equipped with an image stacking program and a 4-megapixel digital camera were used to obtain the photographs.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Map showing the type locality (black triangle) and other locations of occurrence of
Aegla urussanga
n. sp.
(black circles), unsuccessfully sampled streams (white circles) and occurrence of
A. parana
(white star) in the state of Paraná, Brazil. The black triangle and black circles surrounded by white circles indicate animals that were sequenced. The dark gray area indicates the basin named Paraná 3.

subSection.paragraph:
Genomic DNA was extracted from tissues preserved in absolute alcohol, using MagMax Kits (Applied Biosystems) and Wizard® Genomic DNA Purification (Promega), following the manufacturers' recommendations. The cytochrome c oxidase subunit I mitochondrial gene region (COI, ~900 bp) was amplified using COI-f and COI-r primers ( Van Syoc 1995 ), following the PCR conditions proposed by Pérez-Losada et al . (2002) adapted by Marçal et al. (2021). PCR products were stained with SYBR® Safe DNA Gel Stain (Life Technologies) and visualized on 1% agarose gel. Subsequently, they were purified with ExoSAP IT® (Prodimol Biotecnologia) and sequenced. Sequencing reactions were performed independently for both strands using the Big Dye Terminator Kit v 3.1 (Applied Biosystems) and the product of the sequencing reactions was analyzed on an ABI 3500 XL automated sequencer (Applied Biosystems Inc., CA, USA ). Sequences were aligned and edited in MEGA v. 6 (
Tamura et al . 2013
). For the analysis, sequences of
Aegla species
were added, which are also available on GenBank.

The species that make up the molecular analysis were chosen for their morphological similarity and geographical proximity (occurrence in the same basin or in adjacent river basins). The species from the Iguaçu River Basin, south border with BP3, are
A. parana
(AY595564), which we here call
A. parana
1, from the municipality of Lapa ( 25°39'S , 49°50'W ) and
A. parana
which we here call
A. parana
2 (AY595565) from the municipality of Rio Negro ( 26°03'S , 49°43'W ) (Pérez-Losada, et al . 2004),
A. parva
(AY595592),
A. okora (
MZ920243),
A. meloi
(KT319207),
A. lancinhas
(FJ360707), and
A. schimitti
(AY595563).

Because there are no records of
Aegla
in the Piquiri River Basin, north border with BP3, species from the Tibagi River Basin were included ((AY595586)
A. castro
; (MZ870583)
A. jacutinga
; ( AEGLA 004)
A. abrupta
; ( AEGLA 009)
A. nanopedis
; ( AEGLA 005)
A. santosi
; (MZ870571)
A. lata
) from the Ivaí River Basin ((MZ920248)
A. nebeccana
; (KT319211)
A. loyolai
), of the Cinza River Basin ((AEGPR016)
A. buenoi
) the Litorânea River Basin ((AY595559)
A. marginata
). Sequences generated in this study were deposited at Bold Systems under accession numbers OQ868164, OQ868165, OQ868166, OQ868167, OQ868168, OQ868169, OQ868170.

To test the hypothesis of new species, three species delimitation methods were used: intra and interspecific genetic distance, calculated based on Kimura 2 parameters ( Kimura, 1980 ), using the software MEGA v. 6; Generalized Mixed Yule-Coalescent ( GMYC ) (Pons et al . 2006); Assemble Species by Automatic Partitioning ( ASAP ). For the GMYC analysis, an ultrametric tree was generated by Bayesian inference in BEAST v. 2.6.2 (Bouckaert et al . 2019) with a strict molecular clock and a birth-death model (Heled and Drummond, 2010). Data were analyzed as a single partition and the evolutionary model used was HKY+I+G (proportion of invariant sites = 0.5770; previously specified by jModelTest2 (Darriba et al . 2012). Analyses were performed for 10 million generations, sampling a tree every 1000 generations. TRACER v. 1.5 (BEAST package) was used to verify the subsequent probability of sufficient minimum effective size (ESS> 200) and a significant estimate of the parameters and average node age, considering a burn-in of 25 million generations. The trees were summarized and visualized using the programs TREEANNOTATOR 1.5.3 and FIGTREE 1.3.1, respectively (Drummond and Rambaut, 2007; Rambaut, 2009). The GMYC were generated online (http://species.h-its.org/ptp/). ASAP analyzes were run on the online platform (https://bioinfo.mnhn.fr/abi/public/asap/) using Kimura (K80) distance matrices and the remaining parameters were left as default.

materialsCitation.location: set of drainages named Parana 3 River Basin

238 m
,
October 2022
, T. Arantes , G. M. Barbosa , MZUEL 545 .

, MZUEL 525
;

;

,

;

;

,

,

– 14.4 ), Toledo , nameless stream, 24°48'43.3''S , 53°42'31.3''W ,

,

;

,

.

Additional material for DNA extraction.
1 juvenile and 1 adult , holotype data,
July 2021
, MZUEL 523
;
2 juveniles , MZUEL 533
;
2 juveniles , MZUEL 534
; 1 juvenile , 578; 1 juvenile 579 used for DNA extraction.

Diagnosis. Carapace anterolateral spine not reaching the base of the cornea; outer orbital margin bluntly rounded; shallow and open extraorbital sinus; non-elevated epigastric prominences indicated by scales; protogastric lobes robust, scaled. Anterior margin of abdominal epimeron 2 with a pronounced concavity (in dorsal view) and lateral spine. Thoracic sternite 3 tapered with armed apical end. Chelipeds with sub-rectangular palmar crest; ischium inner ventral surface with proximal stout spine, distal stout spine, and up to 3 tubercles with spiniform scale.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Aegla urussanga
n. sp.
, male holotype, CLE 22.0 mm, Paraná 3 River Basin, Paraná, Brazil, MZUEL 545: A, dorsal view of cephalothorax and anterior portion of abdomen; B, ventral view of ischium of greater cheliped (left) with two spines and one tubercle; C, third sternite abrupt with armed apical end; D, dorsal view of anterior margin of epimeron 2 with very pronounced concavity ending with sharp spine. Scale: A = 10.0 mm; B–D = 1.0 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Holotype description.
Cephalothorax slightly convex, gastric region convex, scabrous dorsal surface. Rostrum triangular, base narrow ( RBW /LMR = 0.93), extending beyond apex of eyes, carinated along entire length, slightly deflected dorsally; dorsal carina beginning at level of protogastric lobes, with row of corneous scales extending to apex; subrostral margin with well-developed, obtusely rounded process, occupying the proximal one-third of margin ( Fig. 4B ). Carapace anterolateral spines with corneous, acuminate apex, not reaching base cornea. Orbital sinuses deep, extraorbital sinuses shallow; outer orbital margin bluntly rounded, unarmed. Epigastric prominences not elevated, demarcated by subtle scales. Protogastric lobes pronounced, with corneous scales. Gastric region elevated above hepatic lobes. The demarcation between the first and second hepatic lobes is clearly defined, while the demarcation between the second and third hepatic lobes is weak on the left side but well-defined on the right side. Lateral margins of hepatic lobes with small corneous scales.

Cervical groove with subtrapezoidal shape. Sub-rectangular areola (AH/[( APM +AAD)/2] = 2.08). Trapezoidal cardiac area ( TDL /PMC = 1.28) ( Fig. 2A ). Triangular epibranchial area, slightly elongated, with a small spine at its apex and the lateral line acuminated by scales, anterolateral angle with corneous scales, lateral margin with a row of corneous scales ( Fig. 4A ). Lateral margins of anterior and posterior branchial regions with row of corneous scales.
Thoracic sternite 3 tapered, apex armed; sternite 4 also armed ( Fig. 2C , 5B ).
Abdominal epimeron 2 (in dorsal view) with pronounced anterior concavity ending with sharp lateral spine ( Fig. 2D , 5A ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Aegla urussanga
n. sp.
, male holotype, CLE 22.0 mm, Paraná 3 River Basin, Paraná, Brazil, MZUEL 545. Scale = 10.0 mm.

FIGURE 4.
Aegla urussanga
n. sp.
, male holotype, CLE 22.0 mm, Paraná 3 River Basin, Paraná, Brazil, MZUEL 545: A, dorsal view of anterior region of cephalothorax showing trapezoidal cervical sulcus (black arrow) and shortened epibranchial area (white arrow); view of anterior region of cephalothorax showing pronounced protogastric lobes (white arrow) and welldeveloped subrostral process (black arrow). Scale = 1.0 mm.

FIGURE 5.
Aegla urussanga
n. sp.
, male holotype, CLE 22.0 mm, Paraná 3 River Basin, Paraná, Brazil, MZUEL 545: A, dorsal view of anterior margin of epimeron 2 with very pronounced concavity (white arrow) ending with sharp spine (gray arrow); B, third sternite (black arrow), fourth sternite spines (white arrows). Scale = 1.0 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Variations. Females and small individuals of both sexes have conical tubercles or spines and scattered bristles on the cheliped palmar crests, with variation in number of these structures (Fig. 7, 8). The ventromesial margin of the ischium may vary in shape and number of tubercles between the larger spines, and may be absent and have up to 3 tubercles or scales. The spine of abdominal epimeron 2 may be smaller than that of the holotype . In small individuals, the distal spines on the dorsal surface of the merus of the second pereiopod may be reduced to tubercles or acute scales.

Etymology. The specific epithet is derived from the Tupi-Guarani language, the word "Urussanga is formed by two words from the indigenous language, meaning "place of a river with very cold water", referring to the type locality, Urussanga community.

Molecular data. We analyzed 916 base pairs (bp) of the COI gene with an excellent resolution. The genetic distances between
A. urussanga
n. sp.
and its congeners ranged from 1.2% to 5.1% ( Tab. 1 ), with the species with the lowest genetic distance being
A. castro
(1.2%),
A. parana
1 (1.4%),
A. buenoi
(1.7%),
A. jacutinga
(1.7%),
A. meloi
(1.7%)
and A. parva
(1.9%).
Aegla marginata
exhibited the highest divergence from the new species at 5.1%. Both GMYC and ASAP analyzes ( Fig. 9 ) suggests the presence of 17 distinct species, separating
A. parana
into two clades.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 8. Aegla urussanga
n.sp.
, Ovigerous female, of very small size (CLE 9 mm), incubating 16 eggs, MZUEL 533. Scale = 1 mm.

FIGURE 9. Bayesian tree (HKY+I+G) for species of
Aegla
based on partial COI gene sequences. Generalized Mixed YuleCoalescent (GMYC) (Bayesian analysis) and Assemble Species by Automatic Partitioning (ASAP) (genetic distance analysis) both test for species delimitation. The vertical bars, from left to right, indicate GMYC and ASAP, respectively.

subSection.paragraph:
In general morphology, the aeglids are very similar to each other ( Schmitt 1942 ), but detailed analysis of the morphology and the comparison with the species already described allows the recognition of a set of characters that enable the separation of the new species. The molecular results corroborate the morphological analysis, and the two methods used for species delimitation confirm
Aegla urussanga
n. sp.
as a separate taxon.

Using the identification key for the species of South-Brazilian and Peri-Platinas
Aegla
available in Bond-Buckup & Buckup, (1994) we arrive at
A. perobae Hebling & Rodrigues, 1977
, which, however, has as type locality the Tietê River sub-basin in São Paulo – Brazil , approximately 700 km away from BP3. The similarities between the two species are: ocular peduncles of normal dimensions; rectangular or sub-rectangular palmar crest of cheliped; proximal outer margin of mobile finger of cheliped without lobe; carinated rostrum along full length; anterolateral spine of the carapace not reaching the base of the cornea. On the palmar crest of
A. urussanga
n. sp.
it is not excavated as in
A. perobae
, another difference in this structure is the presence of horny spines on the margin in
A. perobae
and an unarmed margin in adults of the new species. Slightly elevated epigastric prominences are present in
A. perobae
and absent in
A. urussanga
. In
A. urussanga
the anterodorsal margin of abdominal epimeron 2 is distinctly concave and armed, compared with almost straight and unarmed in
A. perobae
.

Aegla urussanga
n. sp.
was found in the same basin as
A. parana
(see Bond-Buckup & Buckup, 1994 ), with about 80 km separating their respective sites. However, there is also a record of
A. parana
from Iguaçu River Basin, in the municipality of Rio Negro, Paraná – Brazil , approximately 500 km from BP3. Furthermore, there are a few similarities between
A. urussanga
n. sp.
and
A. parana
, such as slightly elevated protogastric lobes indicated by scales, and the proximal outer margin of the cheliped dactyl without a lobe. However,
A. parana
is the Brazilian species with the largest number and size of spines, in contrast to the morphological characteristics of the new species, which has fewer and relatively smaller sizes, when compared to
A. parana
. In addition, in
A. parana
, the anterolateral spine of the carapace is long and exceeds half of the cornea, the rostrum is very long and narrow (styliform) in dorsal view and the pereiopods are armed with a series of spines, morphological characteristics quite different from those of
A. urussanga
n. sp.
. Molecular analyses also indicate an interspecific distance of 1.2% between
A. urussanga
n. sp.
and
A. parana
1 and 3.3% in relation to
A. parana
2 (this population, according to
Pérez-Losada et al . (2004)
, occurs in the municipality reported by Schmitt (1945) as the type locality of
A. parana
), thus suggesting that they too could be distinct species ( Table 1 ).

caption.paragraph: TABLE 1. Interspecific and intraspecific genetic distances based on the mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase I (COI) gene. Values are shown as percentages. Intraspecific distances are in bold.

subSection.paragraph:
In relation to the other species that occur in the Iguaçu River Basin, the common characteristics that distinguish
A. parva
,
A okora
,
A. meloi
,
A. lancinhas ,
and
A. schmitti
from
A. urussanga
n. sp.
are the anterior margin of the abdominal epimeron 2 is distinctly concave and the anterolateral angle is sharp in the new species. In the species from Iguaçu the anterior margin is straight or almost straight and in
A okora
,
A. meloi
, and
A. lancinhas
the anterolateral angle is also unarmed. The species from Iguaçu have a corneous orbital spine or tubercle, in
A. urussanga
n. sp.
the angle bluntly rounded. The palmar crest of the new species is sub-rectangular, resembling only
A. meloi
and
A. parva
, but in the latter, the palmar crest has tubercles. Another striking feature is the anterolateral carapace spine, which in
A. urussanga
n. sp.
does not reach the base of the cornea, resembling
A. meloi
, but differing from the other species from Iguaçu. The ornamentation of the ventral face of the cheliped ischium of
A. urussanga
n. sp.
resembles that of
A. parva
and
A. schmitti
, and is not shared with the other species in this basin.

Compared with the species of the Tibagi River Basin, in
A. lata
,
A. castro
,
A. jacutinga
,
A. abrupta
,
A. nanopedis ,
and
A. santosi
, the epigastric prominences are raised or slightly raised, while in
A. urussanga
n. sp.
they are absent, evidenced only by small scales, to like the protogastric lobes. The anterior margin of the abdominal epimeron 2 in species from Tibagi is straight, almost straight, or slightly concave, and the anterolateral angle is unarmed, whereas in
A. urussanga
n. sp.
it is distinctly concave and armed. The palmar crest of the new species clearly differing from species from the Tibagi river basin, which have a disciform or sub-disciform palmar crest.

The species from the Ivaí Basin,
A. nebeccana
and
A. loyolai
, have anterolateral carapace spines that reach the base of the cornea, unlike
A. urussanga
n. sp.
. The triangular rostrum with a narrow base and the subrostral process are similar in
A. urussanga
n. sp.
but they differ from
A. loyolai
by having an elongated, styliform rostrum without a subrostral process. The palmar crest is distinct for the three species, in
A. loyolai
it is sub-disciform to disciform, in
A. nebeccana
it is rectangular, and in
A. urussanga
n. sp.
, sub-rectangular.

Aegla buenoi ,
the only species recorded to date from the Cinzas River Basin, has raised and oval epigastric prominences, unlike
A. urussanga
n. sp.
that only has demarcation by small scales.
Aegla buenoi
has very evident orbital spines, whereas in the new species the angle is bluntly rounded. The anterior margin of the abdominal epimeron 2 is almost straight in
A. buenoi
, and the anterolateral angle has a corneous scale, unlike
A. urussanga
n. sp.
, which is distinctly concave and armed. The cheliped palmar crest of
A. buenoi
is disciform, rather than sub-rectangular in the new species. The ventral face of the ischium of
A. urussanga
n. sp.
has a proximal and distal spine, and up to three tubercles between them, unlike
A. buenoi
which has four or five tubercles.

In the Litoral River Basin,
A. marginata
occurs, which has an anterolateral carapace spine reaching the base of the cornea, differing from the new species. The epigastric prominences in
A. marginata
are present and elevated, (absent in
A. urussanga
n. sp.
). The anterolateral angle of abdominal epimeron 2 is unarmed in
A. marginata
, but armed in the new species. The palmar crest is absent in
A. marginata
, but sub-rectangular in
A. urussanga
n. sp.

Based on the Bayesian tree, the results of the molecular analysis of the COI gene provide support for species delimitation already observed for
Aegla
. The minimum interspecific distance observed (2%) was close to values observed in other species of this genus (
Paez et al . 2018
;
Marçal et al . 2020
; Marçal et al . 2021; Santos et al . 2022). Our delimitation analysis also suggests that the sequences named
A. parana
correspond to two distinct species, as already seen in
Pérez-Losada et al. (2004)
.

These characteristics that promote isolation and differentiation are very well observed in
Aegla longirostri Bond-Buckup & Buckup, 1994
, which was thought to be only one widely distributed species, but which has been shown to potential comprise 14 species (
Crivellaro et al . 2018
), as well as the very close occurrence of
A. nanopedis
,
A. abrupta
and
A. santosi (Marçal et al . 2021)
. This work reveals a wide distribution of
Aegla urussanga
n. sp.
in BHP3, occurring in currently isolated flows. However, this isolation is provided by the Itaipu hydroelectric reservoir, built in 1982 (https://www.itaipu.gov.br/nossahistoria; accessed 09 Apr 2023 ). Prior to that date, the hydrographic network in the region was more complex and many of the watercourses that drained into the reservoir were connected before flowing into the Paraná River.

Little can be said about the biology of
Aegla urussanga
n. sp.
, but during sampling we found an ovigerous female of very small size (CLE 9 mm ), incubating 16 eggs . Similar records (CLE ~9.00 mm) of sexual maturity at a small size (CLE ~9.00 mm) were reported for
A. platensis
by Bueno & Bond-Buckup (2000) and Sokolowicz (2005), the latter identifying the presence of germ cells in early stages of maturation and noting that gonadal maturation begins early in females.

Our work increases the knowledge of the diversity of
Aegla
for the Alto Paraná region and presents the second species described for BP3 and the 94th species described in the genus. However, BP3 is a region highly impacted by agriculture, where, probably, many populations of aeglids became extinct before we discovered their existence. In the current work, in four locations with potential for the occurrence of
Aegla
, these animals were not recorded. In this way, any new finding in this small river basin is of great relevance regarding the conservation of aeglids. We emphasize the great importance of preserving these drainage basins and the need for further studies due to the high potential for discovery of new species, expanding knowledge about the distribution and biology of aeglids.

We would like to thank Gabrieli Macedo Barbosa for assistance in collecting specimens. The Museu de Zoologia of the Universidade Estadual de Londrina for laboratory equipment, photographs, and molecular analysis. Thanks to Robin Hambly for reviewing the English text. We also thank the anonymous reviewers and editors for their reviews of the manuscript. TA thanks the Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico (CNPq) for support (no. 134945/2022-0). GMT thanks the Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico (CNPq) for a productivity grant (no. 303802/2022-7).
